The poem is by John Donne, an English poet, satirist, and Anglican priest. The poem is "The Sun Rising." Here's the poem:

"The Sun Rising"

Busy old fool, unruly sun,
Why dost thou also rise?
Take down those thund'ring clouds, and rain from thee
And pour water o'er this land, to end their strife.

At whose remonstrance pride in their rebellious horns
Held it in scorn and set it at defiance.

The sun is risen, and so
Kiss him it doth; for a kiss
Takes in what part it finds:
So then up and call him, thou fairest star,
Up, that on him doth rise, and calls his dawn
To chase away his night and to put him in his bed.

I dare not think that a mortal would have put his head
Into his bed; and to do so, I would not.
No, I dare say, do not suppose him to have done it,
For indeed it would make me fear that he might turn
His light to dark, and make more noise in it,
But with the sun, all his nois is stilled;
His fiery arms he gently wolds at his rest
